content: I don't remember who but one of you out
there asked me to do this so if it was you feel free to leave a comment we've
made a lot of clip-on features on the channel for our modular dungeon tiles
and all of them to anyone has had a single thing in common they all fit and
are made for one tile respect a question why don't you make a double sized clip
on double we're gonna triple it son go big or go home let's get to the table
and as we've discussed before all it takes is a Google image search to find
some inspiration and came across this so we'll go with it
as always for clip-ons we start with double corrugated cardboard because it
is conveniently 1/4 inch thick I'm gonna measure and cut out this shape use a
metal ruler and a good sharp knife then going to take some foam board and cut to
of this shape peel the paper off of one side by the way this is ready board
which can be found at Dollar Tree it's good because it peels easily if you're
not based in the US or you can't get ready board try rubbing alcohol or water
soap to loosen the paper anyway texturized it with some balled up
aluminum foil then glue it to the center piece with white PVA glue as you see
here notice that the two sides of foam create a half-inch clip at the bottom
now check the width of the sandwich and then get some cereal box or similarly
thick cardstock and cut a strip dry fit it and crease it then hot glue it on to
cover that corrugation and make the whole thing stronger do the same for
that exposed corrugation on the interior of the frame world's your oyster at this
point if you're fairly artistic then you got a blank foam canvas to carve into
maybe some shapes or a dragon head or something I am not so I'm reading my
bits bin these little circular flat beads have what kind of looks like a
warrior's head on them I can't tell for sure whatever they're going on and I'm
gonna use some chipboard which is this very thick cardstock and attach some
thin strips again referring to the inspirational image from the beginning
and these gothic beads here too so you get the idea just decorate this up
however you like and then poor man's primer coat everything with white glue
this will seal those elements down and if they're slick it's gonna give the
paint something to grab on to it does help to dip your brush in water a bit to
help that glue flow so base in black paint and then two Gray's first the dark
this is a healthy dry brush or the entire thing
you can see how that roughed up foam surface is just doing so much work for
us and then a lighter gray less powerful dry brush maybe 50% of what you just did
and then interior frame I actually fully based with the light gray just to break
things up a bit you have a second texture also a quick light Nick at all
the edges with plain white will really help to make that stone pop and from
here just more bits gems and beads and stuff I'm going to attach to that
interior frame and spruce it up you could also draw on runes or something
just go crazy and we're about to go to the table to look at the finished
product but real quick some reminders there's a link in the description below
for my storefront has all the tools and supplies that I recommend and for all
you 3d printers out there while ochs crafting vids is sponsored by Heroes
hoard which has an excellent range of high quality models including but not
limited to all true tiles lines which are open lock compatible also check out
my modules over on the DMS guild and remember $3 patrons get free copies of
all my releases okay so I've laid down a basic room here and I'm gonna take one
of these and put on the throne this is from episode 52 in case you're
interested almost pop that on there and slide it
into place and then our archway which is going to basically cover three tiles so
it's intended to have a filled tile in the middle
throw some minis on here and you can see if I already got some other small
clip-ons they're just holding torches so very scenic has a great presence on the
table very happy with how it came out some of the elements might not meet you
know conventional what we'd think of as dwarven architecture but hey I was just
raiding my leftover beads now I know what some of you are thinking right
there on the inside where the gray ends I can see some of the wall underneath
what happened there yeah it was project planning I realized too late what I had
done wrong I guess to mitigate that you could you could have a sandwich of
another material on each side so that the gray extends all the way down but I
don't know with the stone it's really not that big a deal to me yes I said it
and by the way if you want to make your own cardstock miniatures be sure and
visit episode nine if you liked this particular project here's two more that

thanks for joining me and I'll see you next time
